data.title: Intel: The Market Is Taking The Recovery Hopium Way Too Far
data.description:
Intel: Finally Out Of The Doghouse?

Perennial underperformer Intel Corporation (INTC) appears to have finally hammered its way out of the doghouse, as the stock mounted a phenomenal 1Y return of >80%, beating back confidently against the deafening pessimistic clamor, and punishing those that had the temerity to short the stock at the lows, at just below the $19 level.

I've certainly not expected such a breakthrough in bullish sentiments for the erstwhile king of semis, even though its market cap has recovered to just over the $190 billion mark. However, that's miles and miles away from Nvidia's recent $5 trillion market valuation (NVDA) achievement, as semiconductor investors welcome the next phase in this unprecedented AI infrastructure buildout that could stretch through the rest of the decade.

As for Intel, bullish investors who held on to their conviction and added more through the start of this year will likely assert that Intel's worst malaise is behind us. Thus, it should pave the way for the recent outperformance to hang on firmly, and not devolve into another potentially disastrous selloff, as investors scrutinize whether the recent surge has been overstated.

Intel Foundry's Bloodshed Far From Over

Intel's Q3 earnings scorecard demonstrates that execution has clearly improved under the leadership of CEO Lip-Bu Tan. It corresponds to Wall Street's outlook that INTC's margins should have bottomed in late 2024, although foundry continues to be a massive margin bleeder, recording almost -55% in segment operating margin in the third quarter.

Nevertheless, encouraging signals from the ongoing ramp up of Intel's 18A indicates that the low watermark reached last year should be a thing of the past. Accordingly, Intel had already communicated confident guidance in October, as it telegraphed that Panther Lake (based on the 18A process) had moved into volume production, highlighting the positive cadence implied in its roadmap through 2027.

And of course, I had already enunciated the confidence boost that Intel has been afforded by the recent Nvidia investment (which the firm expects to close in 2025), while also having the U.S. government's as one of its cornerstone shareholders. Is Intel foundry ready to prove that 18A could finally be the moment for it to mark a monumental turnaround yet?

Well, I think it's too early for us to ascertain, but the recent progress augurs well as it works on an x86-based chip with Nvidia, which speaks volumes of the company's sticky x86 architecture ecosystem. And management is right to highlight that even as the potential data center capacity is expected to explode multifold through 2030, CPUs are still expected to play a pivotal role in the buildout, providing the runway for Intel to partake in the AI inflection, even though it hasn't quite validated its ability to compete against Nvidia, AMD (AMD) or even Broadcom (AVGO) when it comes to supplying OpenAI (OPEN) with the most cutting-edge of AI chips.

Yet, I thought Qualcomm's (QCOM) recent AI chip unveiling was telling, showing that investors shouldn't write off the chip design capabilities of the semiconductor behemoths like Intel, notwithstanding the struggles that it has been through.

Intel's liquidity and capital allocation strategies are expected to be a lot more disciplined, despite expecting to post a higher CapEx range for 2025 to the tune of $27 billion. Nevertheless, it does appear that the delayed AI PC ramp could experience a much-needed liftoff from 2026/27, as Intel underscored what every investor arguably wanted to hear: the company is supply constrained. It suggests that Intel's demand dynamics have likely been bolstered, which should help to continue paving the way for its operating margins to recover, even though we should be cautious in trying to ascribe too much optimism this early into the ramp.

Intel: Margin Worries Should Subside, But Don't Bank On A Hockey Stick Inflection

While the optionality of having Intel foundry be a positive margins driver in the future is alluring, I believe the market won't be fooled into putting too much hopium into the thesis for now, until validated. And with TSMC (TSM) being so dominant and relied upon right now by the leading chip designers and the hyperscalers, I don't assess it as reasonable for us (yet) to give the benefit of the doubt about the plausible revival in this segment for now.

Hence, while Wall Street forecasts that Intel's CapEx growth should slow down markedly through 2027, the ongoing margin recovery will likely still be driven by the positive outlook in the PC business, while being impeded to a lesser extent due to the ongoing losses in its foundry business. In other words, I believe there's a ceiling on how much operating leverage gains Intel could squeeze out from its unprofitable foundry business, while still relying on a relatively mature PC market to lead the overall recovery.

Buy Or Sell INTC Stock?

And when we consider the incredible surge that saw INTC take out levels last observed in early 2024, I think the momentum is clearly too fast and too furious. Obviously, investors are banking on the renewed vigor underlining its narrative, with the investments inked with the U.S. government and Nvidia as the bedrock of its recent gains.

Because, while I concur that Intel's Q3 release has shown us that execution appears to be firmly on the right track amid a relatively sanguine market right now, I'm not sure whether INTC's >90x forward earnings multiple is truly justified. It seems like the market is betting on an even more spectacular restoration of its business fundamentals through 2027, or even the potential gain of crucial foundry customers due to the assumed lack of foundry capacity to deliver the 250GW in data center capacity that OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is reportedly gunning for.

While these are certainly pivotal aspects in Intel's incredible turnaround story to salivate over, I think the market could have taken their exuberance way too far, as there's still little for Intel to show for in these businesses at the current moment, or even for the foreseeable future.

I don't anticipate Intel announcing a gargantuan partnership with OpenAI at the moment, while hyperscalers are arguably not going to send their custom chips to Intel to fab, if Nvidia isn't leading the way as a flagship customer to validate Intel's production yields first.

These are enough reasons for me to urge investors who didn't manage to join INTC's stellar ascent to sit out, while contemplating other higher-quality setups among its peers.

Rating: Maintain "Hold."

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Dynex Capital: Strong Quarterly Result Buoy DX.PR.C Preferred
data.description:
In this article we catch up on the agency mortgage REIT Dynex Capital (DX) and its preferred (DX.PR.C). The latter trades at a yield of 9.35% (as of today's 3-month term SOFR). We also discuss a number of concerns that investors tend to bring up with respect to the stock. We continue to hold the stock, but for new positions, it would make sense to see it dip closer to $25.40.

Quarter Update

DX had a great quarter for preferreds shareholders. Book value rose 6%. The common share count also increased by 16%. This was a double-barreled benefit to the equity/coverage ratio, which jumped 23%, now sitting at 17x - the highest level in the sector.

Leverage fell from 8.3x to 7.5x - also good to see. The company has tended to be tactical with its leverage, lowering it when agency spreads fall, as was the case during the quarter. That's a favorable strategy, as it means it won’t be too greedy when agencies are expensive and due for a spread widening. This is why its portfolio performed so well over the COVID quarter.

In the sections below, we highlight some of the concerns that investors have expressed regarding the stock as well as the mREIT preferreds sector more broadly.

1. Price Worries

One concern is that falling short-term rates will bring prices lower as well. DX.PR.C is a floating-rate preferred, and Fed rate cuts will push its dividend lower as well. This is a common concern and is highly intuitive - after all, if the stock is now generating less income, wouldn't investors find it less attractive and, hence, sell it, driving the price lower.

The short answer here is that short-term rates are not a significant driver of prices of floating-rate assets. This is for two reasons. One, slightly technical, is that short-term rates drive both the cash flows of the floating-rate security as well as the discount factors that are applied to it in generating a risk-neutral price. When short-term interest rates change, the impact of these factors cancels each other out.

The second reason is more empirical. We can look at the prices of DX.PR.C (which only floated in April of this year) as well as of NLY.PR.F and AGNCN, which have been floating for several years. What we see is that when the Fed cut rates 4 times at the end of 2024, there was no impact on these securities.

Of course, this doesn't mean that floating-rate securities aren't sensitive to anything. Rather, they are sensitive to credit spreads which we can view as either systemic (general risk aversion in credit markets) or something idiosyncratic to the individual asset.

2. Redemption Worries

Another persistent concern that investors have is that the stock will be redeemed. This has two components. One, an income-generating asset may be called away just as there are few other attractive opportunities. And two, there may be a small price hit on the redemption. For example, DX.PR.C trades around 2.8% above "par" in stripped price terms. This means that an immediate redemption would be a hit of around 2% (after accounting for the required notice period and the coupon accrual in that time). That's real money, even if it is made up in a couple of months of accrual.

You'd have to be very unlucky to lose money on the stock on a quick redemption after a purchase. That said, it does make sense to time the purchase on a dip (in stripped price terms). However, if the stock is acquired above "par," the longer the position is maintained, the less impactful is the redemption.

A common question related to the redemption likelihood is why does DX want to pay 9%+ on the preferred when it can fund itself with repo at less than half the rate? The short answer is that the preferred shouldn't be compared with repo because it's not debt. Rather, it is cheap equity. It should be compared not with the repo rate but with the dividend on common shares, which is considerably higher.

Finally, the greatest determinant of preferreds redemption is the level of credit spread now versus time of issuance. The stock was issued shortly before COVID when high-yield credit spreads were around 3.6% at 5.461% over the unsecured short-term rate (3-month Libor at that point). Today's spreads are around 3%. Arguably, the company's preferred credit spread premium over high-yield bonds is less than it was in 2020. It is a more known entity now, and the stock's equity/preferred coverage is higher. Both of these factors suggest that if the company were to refinance, it would pay a lower credit spread than it did when it issued DX.PR.C.

Ultimately, we don't know exactly how much less the market would demand than the original spread of 5.461% today, and neither does the company. There are no other DX preferreds, and the stock is pinned-to-par, i.e., the spread it is paying is higher than it would be for a non-callable security, meaning price discovery is challenging. It's likely the market would settle for quite a bit less than the spread of 5.461%, but there is some uncertainty around this. DX would also have to pay something like 2-3% to refinance DX.PR.C, so all of this creates friction to a refinancing.

In short, we wouldn't be shocked if DX.PR.C is redeemed, but it remains unlikely in our view as the lack of redemption on the first call date is a signal that the company is happy to keep the preferred outstanding.

3. Yield Worries

A final worry is that the drop in short-term rates means the yield of the stock is not particularly compelling. After all, who wants to hold a position whose dividend keeps falling?

However, individual securities don't exist in isolation, so let's see where the stripped yield of DX.PR.C stands relative to its fixed-rate counterpart - high-yield corporate bonds.

If we chart the historic yield differential between the two, we get the following chart. Let's also add the yield level after the 4 or so expected Fed rate cuts filter through.

What we see is that even if we adjust the yield of DX.PR.C based on the coming Fed rate cuts, it will remain at a historically elevated level relative to corporate bonds.

This is due for two reasons. One, the relevant yield curve remains unusually flat, meaning floating-rate securities are generating an attractive level of income relative to fixed-rate securities. One element that is often ignored is that short-term rates don't just affect the base rate of floating-rate securities. They obviously affect the entire yield curve as longer-term rates are simply longer-term expectations of short-term rates plus an inflation premium.

In other words, longer-term rates have already adjusted to the market view of 4-5 more Fed rate cuts to come. And sure, investors can fix that 5-year rate today, but it's not like investors buying fixed-rate bonds can pull a fast one and avoid the rate cuts that are due to affect short-term rates. The coming rate cuts are already baked into long-term rates.

And the second reason why the yield of DX.PR.C is and will remain relatively elevated versus high-yield corporate bonds is that the stock is pinned-to-par. Because it is callable, it is not going to move more than 2-3% above "par" in stripped price terms. This is because investors don't want to take a hit in case the stock is redeemed. And because this dynamic keeps the price anchored around "par", its yield is higher than it would be if the stock were not callable. In short, investors are getting paid a higher yield by virtue of the redemption risk than they would otherwise.

Stance and Takeaways

DX.PR.C remains arguably the best risk/reward in the entire income space at a 9.4% yield (based on today's 3-month term SOFR). This will move lower as the Fed cuts but only very slowly. There is a relatively high call price risk of -2.8%, however, the first call date was in April and the company looks to be in no hurry to redeem it. The stock has been trading a bit above "par" for a long while now and will likely remain pinned-to-par unless credit spreads seriously blow out, perhaps doubling from here. This makes it an unusually low-beta asset as well.

For new positions, we would look for the clean price to move towards $25.40 or so where it drops occasionally. Other stocks in the sector have a lower stripped yield and a lower call price hit in case of redemption - not a coincidence. Investors who worry about this should consider a stock like AGNCP, which has a yield of 8.95% (as of today's 3-month term SOFR) but trades below "par" in stripped price terms, meaning there is no hit in case of redemption.

data.title: Amazon: The Most Misunderstood AI Stock On Wall Street
data.description:
Why now?

Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) deserves a Strong Buy rating, and I'll tell you why right away. I've spoken to several analysts and portfolio managers in recent weeks, who are somewhat skeptical of its strong AI spending. Amazon has increased this spending, so I expect even more skepticism or fear that something might break.

I see it differently.

Today, that spending corresponds to the current moat, a competitive moat that transforms AWS, retail, and advertising into a single growth engine. This spending can be compared to a wall being quietly built with billions of dollars. A wall that serves as a barrier to entry for potential new players. If we then raise this wall with cash and not leverage, all the better.

AWS, which has worried everyone recently, has returned to growth at 20%, and believe me, this isn't an isolated case or a stroke of luck, but rather a capacity for expansion and the company's ability to adopt AI solutions that can be monetized on the balance sheet. Extraordinary expenses weighed negatively on the whole, obscuring the real leverage in North America.

On the other hand, there are AI tools like Rufus and the seller suite drive conversions. We're here, we're in the era of AI that monetizes. It's a reality. There are undoubtedly risks. I address them in the dedicated section below, but at the moment I see more upside potential than downside risks. At these levels, despite the market's post-results reaction, the asymmetry remains favorable. In the long term, I remain positive on the stock and my TP is set within the $269-$286 range.

Overview

When the quarterly results were released, I looked at the results, saw the after-hours reaction, and closed everything. I was calm; I had the stock in my portfolio, and I would have calmly dedicated myself to poring over the financial statements. Then Apple arrived, and I was surprised by its market reaction (first a 5% selloff and then an 8% recovery from the low).

I said to myself: we urgently need to understand what's happening with Apple (AAPL). Amazon, on the other hand, is calm. With a cool head, I started analyzing the stock, and I don't want to bore you with an endless list of financial data. I arrived the next day to write this piece, and in the meantime, even better analysts than me have already analyzed the numbers and highlighted what worked and what didn't. Furthermore, I must say that Seeking Alpha does an excellent job of promptly reporting every company result, so the details are here.

The battle for supremacy in the coming years won't be decided by the most beautiful and brilliant software, the one that does the fastest calculations. I feel like I've said that often. The real winners will be energy stocks (especially nuclear, for example) and chipmakers. In this entire context, Amazon is playing its digital industrial game, increasing capacity, dedicated clusters (Trainium2/Rainier), and expanding order visibility. In all of this, many see capex as a problem, but I see a player buying up compute shares before competitors. It's doing what a shark (or whale) should do: eating everything before the others arrive. Sure, you might get upset sometimes, but in the meantime, you'll be full. The others will starve.

Earnings

I'll start by saying that the published numbers, viewed as they are, don't really tell the story of the quarter. They include one-off costs (such as the FTC fine and severance packages) that make retail margins appear worse than they actually are. If we eliminate these exogenous factors, the situation changes.

In the report, the retail margin appears to be slowing, but in reality, it's a matter of perspective because North America is back where it belongs, with a 6.9% operating margin on $106.3B of sales, not the 4.5% you see at a glance. At the group level, operating income went from $17.4B reported to $21.7B ex-expenses.

This changes the picture, no? I'm not advocating pretending these cost items are not there. Companies naturally come across events of this kind; certainly, income statement is impacted. The question is distinct: how many yearly times do they manifest themselves? Are they "business as usual"? I don't think so. What I'm trying to say is that to see the long term, it might be useful to separate and clean up.

We have achieved actual monetization on the front lines of artificial intelligence. It's concrete rather than marketing. While the Ads department is extending reach beyond the Amazon ecosystem and sustaining very high margins, the Rufus assistant is boosting conversions and frequency of purchase. And so, more demand generated inside, less reliance on outside referrals, and clearer and more environmentally friendly retail profitability.

The AWS segment growing by 20% is what I call the "second cycle" (AI compute and capacity growth). The backlog is significant, and the new clusters—CPUs, GPUs, memory, storage, high-speed networking—are filling up rapidly, and that's the main point. So, we're talking about a phase in which AI is starting to truly monetize and become part of existing business processes.

I'd also like to point out another aspect that I found interesting. Did they mention the tariff issue? No reference in calls; not because they don't exist but rather because the model is immune already (local network, stable 3P mix, high-margin ADS).

Last point: capex. I mentioned it in the introductory part of the article. Some see AI investments as a huge waste of resources, or simply too excessive.

Some build ratios based on GDP, make comparisons with 2000, then go back a few years, adjusting for inflation. In short, there's been a lot of talk lately. For me, capex is simply a barrier, and I'm happy that companies like Amazon want to defend their technological dominance by spending today and reaping tomorrow. As an investor, I'm happy. Those who build first, monetize first. The only thing I'd ask management is the utilization rate of new clusters and ramp times. If they hold up, the FCF compression is tactical and temporary, not structural.

Valuation

As of this writing, I see many analysts raising their target price and confirming their "outperform" rating.

At current prices, I'm not kidding you—we're not at a discount—but if we look at the earnings trajectory, we can be convinced that it might be worth holding and (for those who need to adjust their portfolio) increasing exposure.

The price-earnings ratio is around 33 and declines as earnings grow. I invite you to take a look at the dedicated price-earnings page.

The same is true if we look at the EV/EBITDA ratio, a more industrial metric that also takes debt into account. Currently, it stands at 13.5x, but will decline to 11x in 2027. In essence, the stock becomes cheaper over time, without requiring a change in market sentiment.

At a glance, I've constructed this chart that correlates the stock price, earnings growth (blue bars), and the change in the P/E. Essentially, the stock continues to rise, while the multiple compresses by about 7%, so the performance was earnings-driven, not re-rating-driven. I don't know if I'm explaining myself, but it's a crucial piece of the puzzle. It's obvious that at these valuations, it's difficult to buy everything in the stock—not even I would—but as long as price growth is driven by earnings growth, there's little to argue about. Right?

Operationally, this is what I want to see in a compounding company, and this strengthens the Strong Buy thesis because my target ($270 base; $290–310 bull) doesn't require too many optimistic assumptions because it holds up even with a stable P/E.

For me, the most important factor is "cash." The FCF appears compressed now as a result of large investments in artificial intelligence rather than due of underperformance. Direct consequence of significant investments in AI infrastructure. That being said, the company and Bloomberg analysts forecast a path that slows in 2025, but will recover in 2026. Particularly:

If we compare these numbers to a market cap of around $2.6 trillion, we're looking at an FCF yield that goes from almost zero today to around 2% in 2026, 3% in 2027, and 4–5% in 2028.

It's the classic data center scale effect: first you build, absorb cash, and incur capital expenditures, and then, once capacity is up and running, cash flow explodes and margins follow.

In simple terms? Today, AWS consumes, but in two years it will monetize.

To estimate my target price, I start from the company's "cash" operating profit, i.e., the consensus 2027 EBITDA, and apply a multiplier of 11–12 times. The blend is consistent with the actual mix (highly profitable AWS/Ads + capital-intensive retail), aligned with the consensus normalization toward 11x in 2027, and conservative as long as AI capex remains at its peak. The result leads to an equity value between $260 and $285 per share, which becomes my reference range, i.e., a $270 base case and a $290–$310 bull case if the next few quarters confirm improving margins and continued growth for AWS and advertising.

Conclusions

Amazon is currently a digital infrastructure that is converting capex into a competitive benefit, not only "just" e-commerce.

Because FCF compression will take longer than anticipated if the new clusters aren't running at full capacity, power and chips remain the actual question mark. AWS, with book-to-bill >1 and GW accelerated, can provide an autonomous re-rating in the meanwhile, free of additional specific thrusts. AI "in the shop" (Rufus/Agentic tools) changes conversion and take-rate in a methodical and structural manner.

I am purchasing a postponed cash cycle rather than a guarantee.

data.title: Trump's Asia Tour Was Squarely About One Thing
data.description:
After a 6-day tour abroad, President Trump has returned to America. He visited several countries across Asia, aiming to play peacemaker and dealmaker at each stop, sometimes both at the same time.

It began in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, just before the ASEAN summit.

Peacemaking in Asia: Setting the Tone

President Trump got his peacemaker moment at the first stop. Cambodia and Thailand have been fighting over a stretch of land that has been a thorn in their relations for quite some time. While in Malaysia this week, President Trump oversaw the signing of an agreement between these two countries over their border dispute that has led to a ceasefire, though no long-term peace has been signed yet. It is a step in the right direction and sets the tone of the rest of the tour.

There is no Cambodia ETF that I could find, but the news did do good things for the Thailand ETF. That first steep leg up comes as the announcement of the agreement is made, and then a peak shortly after it's signed (traders "selling the news"). All in all, a good thing.

The Real Reason to Make the Trip

This visit to Malaysia coincided with the 13th annual Association of South-East Nations ("ASEAN") conference being held, which Trump also attended. There, he also met with Brazilian president Lula da Silva.

Both of these endeavors set the tone for the rest of the trip, which I believe was squarely focused on one goal: containing China.

At ASEAN, several deals were made, including (nearly) free trade deals with Malaysia and Cambodia, and made openings to sign similar deals in the future with Thailand and Vietnam.

The US is in a critical mineral shortage, covered in detail in "The Critical Materials Rally Will Continue," when I presented this chart:

For reference, the "New Axis" is China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela.

In that article, I gave some context about how this happened:

For the longest time, this [arrangement] was seen as acceptable [to the West] for a few reasons:

  • We avoided the pollution in the US, as the production of many of these materials is very dirty.
  • We could always buy these materials from China should we (and we do) need them.

Now that #1 isn't an issue with the current administration, we can focus on #2 — why not just buy these things from China?

Trade War 2.0 has China now threatening our supply of rare earth elements because they understand this discrepancy can be used to harm us and therefore is a solid negotiating tactic...

I suspect that one of the ways in which the US will continue to fight back against this discrepancy, especially in the wake of these threats to restrict rare earth exports out of China, is to invest further into the sector, like they already have with MP Materials (MP), Lithium Americas (LAC), and Trilogy Metals (TMQ). The Department of Defense (War?) has been investing in these operations, giving them the necessary liquidity and impetus to expand operations and close the gaps in our materials mining and processing.

This will likely extend to other miners as well but will boost the whole industry, which the current administration intends to continue propping up.

Solving this won't just happen with American companies, and while I'm most bullish on domestic firms see my article, "Picking the Winners of the US Rare Earth Response," we will no doubt need the cooperation of our allies in the Pacific if it means securing independence from the Chinese critical mineral supply chain.

ASEAN and Brazil Deals

So, it's natural that the entire rest of the trip seems to be about securing these deals with critical minerals and strategic industries that will assist in containing China's influence over strategic supply chains. Critical mineral MOUs were signed with Malaysia and Thailand, and a potential deal with Brazil was ironed out on the sidelines.

Brazil is of importance here because they have been stepping in to provide China with food exports while they have been forgoing US soybeans in protest of trade policy changes. China does not produce as much food as it consumes and so relies on these exports to sustain its population. Initially in April, the US was hoping to use this food export reliance as leverage in trade negotiations with China, but it fell flat when Brazil was able to step in and fill the gap. A deal with Lula will be helpful to Trump because Brazilian cooperation is essential for the China containment policy to work.

Japan Lowers Their Tariffs

After ASEAN, President Trump headed to Japan, which had just elected its first female Prime Minister, Takaichi. There, the 25% tariff initially put on Japanese goods has been lowered to 15%.

This came in exchange for a pledge of a $550 billion investment in the US. I assume that this will come in the form of foreign direct investment made into Japanese companies' operations in the United States, say Toyota (TM) or Honda (HMC). The timeline for this is currently unclear.

Notably here, President Trump told Prime Minister Takaichi that the U.S. is "an ally at the strongest level," and to call him if there is "anything I can do to help Japan."

It remains to be seen what this means in practice, but a lowering of Japanese tariffs was certainly a good start. Japanese car manufacturers have been eating the tariffs outright since they were announced, likely hoping for an outcome like this that allows them to recover some profit margin without having raised prices on consumers.

South Korea Makes a Deal

Seoul also had their tariffs drop from 25% to 15%, and they agreed to invest $350 billion into the US. The details here were about as sparse as those in Japan, as one can expect when deals are announced in a flurry like this.

Because of liquidity concerns with the Won, there were deals made to split the investments up into installments, capped at $20B/year. This flow could take a very long time. $150B of it is specifically marked for shipbuilding—another way in which the US needs to compete with China and has fallen behind tremendously.

The South Korea ETF gained tremendously on the news, with an outsized reaction compared to Japan despite a very similar deal. My guess here is that the South Korea deal was more of a surprise to the market, whereas the Japan deal seemed to have been priced in already.

It makes sense looking back. I would have expected Japan to be closer to a deal than Korea, and I didn't expect Korea to make a deal here either.

A Meeting With The Dragon

I'll get straight to it: the big announcement was a trade truce that should last for one year. Specifically, the Chinese rare earth restrictions are being discussed, as well as American AI chip restrictions.

We get gallium and graphite; they get NVIDIA's (NVDA) Blackwell.

The truce lasting for one year is problematic because it's just kicking the can down the road, but it allows for the economy to continue in its current shape while we work towards independence in these areas. Without China, there is no American economy that works the way that it currently does. We just import too many important things, specifically magnets and rare earths.

We can't just cut them out and say we don't want the rare earths. We need them to keep economic activity at the level it currently is.

This is why the other trade deals surrounding the meeting with China were so important. Making a trade truce doesn't solve our problem. We still don't have the gallium and graphite long-term, but in the short term, while we build out those deals with allies, we can keep this supply from China coming in smoothly.

Whether you agree with this strategy or not is different from whether it's being implemented. It is.

The news saw both American and Chinese markets sell off, but the US rebounded, while Chinese markets continued to erase gains made the past week of the tour following the announcement of the truce.

A Change in Tone

What was also interesting surrounding this were the leaders' comments about each other, where they discussed each other as peers and rivals depending on who they were speaking to.

It reminds me of when China began to join the WTO and ascended to the world stage in the 1990s.

In May 1993, President Bill Clinton said: "We are prepared to build a more cooperative relationship with China and wish to work with China as an active member of the international community."

In July 1993, President Jiang Zemin said: "For the foreseeable future, the United States will remain our primary adversary..."

To those that were watching closely, it was a clear sign of an asymmetry in our relationship. That's the same asymmetry that Trump is trying to address now, 30 years later.

That asymmetry is gone now, as both leaders talk openly about being both peers and rivals, not just one or the other. It was clear that neither side felt like they secured the win they wanted, which is standard in negotiating, but is not how anyone wants their negotiations to end. For now, we have a truce, while we build independence and work with our allies to create a strategic supply chain that doesn't include a country that considers us its primary adversary.

That quote is from 1993, but if you had told me President Xi said it following this meeting, I would believe you. So would most analysts.

Conclusion

Ultimately, there is an impetus for the United States to secure itself strategically. That includes securing strong relationships with our partners and containing our adversaries, both militarily and economically.

My view of the situation is still that rare-earth firms continue to benefit despite the trade truce, which saw a sell-off in some rare-earth stocks. The overall macro situation for them remains mostly unchanged; it is overwhelmingly bullish from my view. The US and its allies need to secure these supply chains, regardless of how long they have access to them via China. Relying on China just isn't sustainable long-term, and so the investment into these firms will likely continue at full speed once the government re-opens.

Much of the foreign investment promised out of Japan and South Korea will go to strategic supply chains as well, like shipbuilding and domestic manufacturing. This will take time, and it is unclear what the full road of investment looks like. I am eager for more details.

Thanks for reading.

data.title: FormFactor: The Positives May Be Priced In For Now
data.description:
Introduction

FormFactor, Inc. (FORM) reported very positive numbers, which sent its shares over 24% for the day, on the back of improved operational performance and a return to growth in sequential sales. I wanted to take a look at the numbers in more detail and give some comments on the outlook and why I am not particularly itching to start a position.

Since the last time I covered the company, it has done tremendously as its share price doubled in just three months. I said that the future looks very good, but I held off from giving it a buy rating as I had some reservations.

By The Numbers

Starting from the top, sales topped $202.6m, down 2.6% y/y, but slightly beat analysts’ estimates by $2.6m. DRAM probe cards grew double-digits and were the main contributor to the performance that could have been much worse. The systems segment also experienced growth due to higher initial volume production of co-packaged optics. The company began to see some sequential growth, which is good to see. Looking at the breakdown of sales in a bit more detail, we can see that DRAM sales were clearly the best performer this quarter, while Foundry & Logic saw some softness within the Probe Cards Segment.

In terms of regional breakdown, South Korea seems to be the standout in terms of demand for the company’s products, while China is starting to show some action and is slowly coming back up. The US, on the other hand, is also showing some softness.

Let’s have a look at the company’s operational performance. Q3 Non-GAAP EPS came in at $0.33, beating consensus by $0.08. A decent margin. The company’s GAAP margins saw a particularly strong improvement of around 250bps sequentially to almost 40%, while non-GAAP GM came in at 41%. These improvements can be attributed to overall operational efficiencies, cost controls, and labor reductions. The company’s non-GAAP operating margins improved significantly since Q2’25 by around 270bps, leading to the net income increase to $15.66m from $9.09m in Q2, while non-GAAP bottom line came in at $25.68m.

Looking at the company’s financial situation, FORM finished the quarter with around $97.6m in cash and equivalents, as well as $168.3m in marketable securities, against $11m in long-term debt. That is essentially no debt, since the company’s liquidity far outweighs the obligations on debt. The company’s balance sheet continues to improve, and I don’t see anything wrong with it. It’s quite strong. The company is flush with cash and will no doubt easily survive any major downturns in the economy.

On top of these results, management was kind enough to provide us with some updated numbers for the next quarter. The management now expects to make around $210m in sales, which comes in above the estimates of $199.6m, while adjusted EPS should be around $0.35, which is also well above consensus estimates of $0.29, with gross margin forecasted to reach 42%.

Overall, the results were decent. Sales are beginning to pick up, while the company’s operations have improved significantly in just one quarter. On top of that, the company raised guidance for the rest of the year, coupled with a beat on top and bottom lines, investors sent the company’s shares up over 24% for the day. I think this sort of reaction was a bit too much. Sure, the operational improvements are nice, but top-line growth was still non-existent y/y, but my best guess is that due to a decent sequential improvement, investors believe the company is ready to return to growth. Also, I believe investors are very positive about the company’s DRAM and HBM performance, which are critical for AI. Some analysts raised the company’s price target significantly following the results, due to improved margins, assigning a PT of $44 from $23. A massive bump, which no doubt helped fuel this rally. The PT is still much lower than what the company trades at, but such a boost is telling.

Comments On The Outlook

Management has been doing a tremendous job of getting the company’s efficiency and profitability to where they used to be just one year ago, and I believe those numbers will be improved upon over the next few quarters, especially if the demand for everything AI-related continues the way it has. And I am very certain that this AI hype is not going anywhere for at least another few years. The reason I think so is because the main players in the AI/data center space have all reported their earnings over the last two days, and all of which have not only raised their capex spend from previous estimates for the rest of the year, but also provided not-so-cryptic messaging about the next year’s capex to be significantly higher than 2025’s. So, this means there is going to be a lot of money thrown around still in this AI race, and this only means that companies that have anything to do with AI and data centers will see some sort of a boost for much longer. The stock has already more than doubled since the lows in April, and with the recent results and guidance numbers, investors expect this growth to continue.

More demand means fixed cost per unit can be spread out more efficiently, leading to higher margins overall, as long as pricing remains stable or decreases. Hype trends like AI are going to continue to drive demand for the company’s products; it’s just a matter of the company actually capturing more of that demand.

The company may not see a lot of growth right now, even if hyperscalers are shoveling billions of dollars into AI. However, due to longer lead times and being somewhat of a specialized semiconductor testing company, I expect growth to come in eventually, which is why, I believe, is the reason we saw such a jump in share price on October 30. Investors are already pricing it in.

Closing Comments

For this reason, I am going to maintain my hold rating, as I believe the growth has been more or less priced in after this massive jump in share price today. I can see the management is doing a great thing regarding improved efficiency and profitability; however, such a jump in price can only mean that the future improvements have been accounted for by investors. Unless the company surprises us even more over the next few quarters, like showing a 50% growth in sales. That would be impressive and would warrant having another look at it in a lot more detail.

For now, my exposure to everything AI is already too high; therefore, I am going to sit this one out.

data.title: Verizon's Earnings Beat Proves The 7% Yield Is Sustainable (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Yesterday, Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) released its third quarter earnings. The release beat analyst estimates on earnings per share (EPS) while narrowly missing on revenue. Earnings increased 50% on a reported basis and 1.6% on an adjusted basis. Adjusted EPS was 1.6% ahead of estimates.

Heading into Verizon’s third quarter earnings release, analysts had fairly low expectations for the company. The expected EPS result was for 0% change on a year-over-year basis, and revenue was expected to grow just 2%. Although revenue disappointed relative to even that pretty low bar, the overall results showed an improving margin on just slightly growing sales.

The results reported for the third quarter indicate that Verizon is becoming more profitable over time, and indeed, that is the long-term trend as well. In the table below, you can see that since year-end 2021, VZ’s gross profit has increased from $77.3 billion to $81.49 billion, while its revenue has increased from $133.6 billion to $137 billion. This indicates that the company’s gross profit margin has increased from 57.8% to 59.4%—a non-negligible increase.

So, we have a considerable increase in Verizon’s gross profit, as well as its gross profit margin, yet VZ stock is actually down 30% over a five-year period. It seems like there could be an opportunity here.

The fact that there's a potential opportunity in Verizon stock can be confirmed by looking at the stock’s value rating. According to Seeking Alpha Quant, VZ trades at a mere 8.3 times earnings, contributing to an A- valuation rating. This combined with increasing revenue and gross margins would appear to indicate cheapness.

Now, none of the above means anything if Verizon is destined to have its financial fortunes crumble tomorrow. We always need to attempt to gauge a company’s forward prospects before saying that it is truly cheap. I’ll explore that matter in detail in a later section. For now, I will simply point to the fact that the company has $383 billion in assets–only 5.9% of which are goodwill–and $3.6 billion in cash and marketable securities. This is a treasure chest the company can draw on to outlast competitors in times of stress and which can be used to make new investments. These simple facts bode well for Verizon’s future prospects–though obviously we need to look at much more than just balance sheet health before we can fully render a verdict on the matter.

Another thing investors will want to know about Verizon stock following its third quarter release is its suitability as a dividend stock. Before VZ’s earnings came out, the company had a healthy payout ratio, with Seeking Alpha Quant confirming it at 57.6% for the trailing 12-month period. With VZ having posted positive earnings growth in the third quarter, that ratio is presumably coming down over time. So, VZ’s 7%-yielding dividend is getting better covered by earnings.

When I last covered Verizon stock, I rated it a Buy because of the improvements I saw in its operations. Since then, the company has grown and increased its profitability, while its stock has decreased in price. The underlying value would appear to be greater now. So, I am increasing my rating to Strong Buy.

Earnings Recap

Verizon’s recent earnings release mostly exceeded analyst expectations, boasting the following metrics:

  • $33.8 billion in revenue, up 1.6% year over year (miss by $400 million).

  • $1.17 in reported EPS, up 50%.

  • $1.21 in adjusted EPS, up 1.6% (beat by $0.02).

  • $28 billion in nine-month operating cash flow, up 5.6%.

  • $15.8 billion in nine-month free cash flow (FCF), up 8.9%.

  • $12.8 billion in adjusted EBITDA, up 2.4%.

  • $21 billion in wireless service revenue, up 2.1%.

  • $5.6 billion in wireless equipment revenue, up 5.2%.

  • 261,000 wireless net additions.

  • 306,000 broadband net additions.

  • Guidance for 1% to 3% EPS growth.

  • Guidance for $19.5 billion to $20.5 billion in full-year FCF.

Overall, the headline metrics were all pretty satisfactory. Additionally, there were some nice tidbits of information away in the release as well, for example:

  • There were 61,000 internet net additions in the quarter, the best result seen in two years.

  • Postpaid average revenue per account (ARPA) improved 2%.

  • The company had 13.2 million total broadband customers by the end of the quarter.

  • It also delivered a $6.7 billion reduction in net debt.

These additional facts go to show that Verizon is not only beating earnings expectations but also improving its financial condition as well as customer totals. It looks like a pretty good picture.

Future Prospects

Having looked at VZ’s most recent periodic performance, we can now attempt to gauge its future prospects. I already touched on this in the introduction, when I wrote that the company has a lot of assets and cash with which to invest. That is one competitive edge that could drive future growth for VZ. Another, less measurable (but still important) edge the company has is a strong focus on premium plans. While telcos in general don’t enjoy much pricing power, with service prices declining long-term, there are segments of the telco market where suppliers have more power. One of those is the “ultra high speed” segment, where unlimited 5G plans can often come at a significant cost to consumers. Customers are often willing to pay up for such plans. This is particularly the case with customers who need constant high-speed internet, such as gamers and business owners. Verizon is investing heavily in servicing such consumers, buying up fibre optic companies to help serve them.

Valuation

Next up, we can look at the multiples that Verizon trades at. At today’s price, VZ is a pretty cheap-looking stock, trading at 8.3 times earnings, 1.2 times sales, and 1.56 times book. You can see more multiples in the image below, courtesy of Seeking Alpha Quant.

One multiple that looks very intriguing here is the PEG ratio, which indicates truly extreme cheapness after factoring in growth. I don’t think that VZ’s earnings growth rate is going to remain at 103% forever–the company doesn’t have the top-line growth to support that–but it should be positive. So, I expect VZ to continue having a respectable PEG ratio, unless its price rises dramatically.

As for what VZ is worth in terms of discounted cash flows:

I found from Capital IQ data that analysts estimate VZ’s cost of equity at 7% and its long-term earnings growth rate at 1.3%. Using these estimates as well as Seeking Alpha Quant’s estimate of VZ’s FCF per share, I got a $85.79 fair value estimate. See workings below:

Risks

Despite all the positive things I’ve written about VZ in this article, I do see the stock and its investors as facing certain risk factors. These include:

  1. Competition. There are many telcos in the United States, and some, such as AT&T Inc. (T) are quite strong and well funded. They could bring competition to Verizon that puts pressure on its margins.

  2. Little pricing power. Verizon does not appear to have much pricing power, as evidenced by the fact that it experienced subscriber loss when it attempted to hike prices earlier this year.

  3. High costs. Telco services are capital-intensive owing to the fact that they run on large amounts of heavy infrastructure. This typically requires them to borrow lots of money, although Verizon has been paying down its debt in recent quarters.

The above risks are worth keeping in mind. However, Verizon’s cheapness more than adequately compensates for them, making the company's stock a buy in my books.

data.title: Undercovered Dozen: Zoomd Technologies, Waste Management, DroneShield And More
data.description:
The Undercovered Dozen is a weekly Seeking Alpha editor-curated series highlighting 12 articles on lesser-covered stocks from the previous seven days. We hope this provides ideas and inspires discussion among the community.

Today, we're looking at articles published between Oct. 24 and Oct. 30.

Take a look at what these less-covered stocks might hold for you. And please join the conversation below to share what you think: Are any of these worth following up on? And are there other undercovered ideas that you like?

Zoomd Technologies: How A Microcap AdTech Player Is Winning The Open Internet Battle

Dmitri Vinokurov | Strong Buy

Zoomd Technologies Ltd. (OTCPK:ZMDTF, ZOMD:CA) is a small yet highly profitable advertising technology firm that is currently in hypergrowth. Despite this, the firm trades at extremely attractive valuations, both on a P/E and FCF growth basis, with the valuations being supported by strong execution of management and sector tailwinds.

Since executing a strategic repositioning in Q2 of 2023, the firm has been able to see growth as high as the high double digits Y/Y, and has turned from unprofitability to net income margins as high as 31%. As repositioning efforts commenced, the company has diversified further between clients and sectors, continued to expand into new, high-margin sectors, and reduced operating expenses through the use of AI and machine learning. On top of this, the firm currently holds no GAAP-accountable debt, strengthening the risk/reward of this investment.

These factors, combined with recent catalysts of bullish analyst coverage and partnerships that expand the reach of Zoomd, all strengthen my bullish thesis in the company.

As part of my analysis of Zoomd Technologies Ltd., I would like to initiate coverage with a "Strong Buy" rating.

Read more here...

Waste Management's Downturn Doesn't Justify It Sitting In The Waste Bin

Daniel Jones | Buy

As a value investor, I prioritize valuation above most other things when it comes to making an investment decision. But there are other factors to consider as well. As an example, I usually give additional wiggle room to high-quality companies with industry-leading positions. And if those businesses are growing at a nice pace, I give even more wiggle room. A great example of this that, recently, has fallen a bit short, is none other than the appropriately named Waste Management (WM). Since I reaffirmed the company as a ‘buy’ candidate in early March of this year, the S&P 500 has shot up 13%. But over that same time, shares of the company have dropped 6.6%. This is disheartening to say the least. But honestly, all this does, in my view, is open up a door for additional purchases for those who are inclined to do so.

The fact of the matter is that Waste Management has achieved strong growth recently. And in all likelihood, that growth will continue for the foreseeable future. In fact, for the upcoming earnings release covering the third quarter of the 2025 fiscal year, which management is supposed to announce on October 28th before the market opens, revenue and profits are both expected to rise. It is true that shares are not as cheap as I would like them to be. But compared to other major players in the market, the stock is certainly affordable. So unless some major negative event comes out of the woodwork, I will almost certainly maintain my ‘buy’ rating on the stock.

Read more here...

Pagaya Technologies: The AI Credit Platform Turning Data Into Durable Profits

Pau Galindo Ortigosa | Strong Buy

Pagaya Technologies (PGY) stock reached a new high of $44.99 on September 19, 2025. The new high comes after the stock rallied more than 400% from its 2025 lows of $9. Following such a huge jump, the market is now beginning to grasp the structural adjustments being undertaken at this AI-driven credit infrastructure company.

While investors focus on the volatility of fintech and legacy credit issues, a more important story might be the “Underwriting Flywheel,” a major shift toward a platform that uses data and partnerships to achieve better efficiency and steady growth in free cash flow over the next three to five years.

This isn’t merely a cyclical upswing in consumer credit. Pagaya is one of the most advanced AI underwriting networks in fintech, moving from breakeven to an enormously profitable credit infrastructure company. Indeed, Pagaya helps 31 lenders and over 145 institutional investors approve loans. The company has reached an important milestone trailing twelve months revenue as of Q2 2025 was $1.15 billion, with $487 million in gross profit (42% margin), EBITDA of $193 million, and operating income of $162 million, all growing at sustainably double digit rates. This durability is being severely discounted at current multiples of about 8x forward EV/EBITDA and about 2.3x forward EV/Sales. An intrinsic value of $39 for Pagaya stock says this analysis: it is a strong buy as re-rating materializes within twelve months.

Read more here...

IonQ And D-Wave Quantum Compared Amid Rumored Trump Administration Investments

APAC Investment News | Buy

Is the Trump Administration looking to invest directly in quantum computing? The Wall Street Journal certainly thinks so, and recently reported that insiders have claimed the United States may make equity investments. That said, a spokesperson for the Department of Commerce denied the claims. Ultimately, I suspect talks are indeed taking place, although currently they may be in so early a stage that it would be inappropriate to announce anything to the public just yet.

What I am confident about is that the Administration will offer strong support for quantum computing. The technology could prove crucial to national defense and the larger economy. In the long run, I believe Alphabet (GOOGL)(GOOG) is the best quantum company to invest in. IBM (IBM) and Microsoft (MSFT) are also appealing, especially in regard to their quantum efforts. That said, small quantum startups also offer interesting high-risk/high-reward investment opportunities worth investing risk capital in. Any major technological breakthroughs by these companies could send them to the moon.

Both IonQ, Inc. (IONQ) and D-Wave Quantum Inc. (QBTS) are good choices in my opinion, and because the companies take substantially different approaches to quantum technologies, investors can diversify their quantum investments to some extent.

Read more here...

Canadian Natural Resources: Competitive Leadership And New Sanctions Create Conditions For Growth

Dmytro Lebid | Buy

The recent news that has shaken the oil market opens up additional potential for strategic growth for companies involved in oil production in Canada. The Canadian Natural Resources Limited (CNQ) is the largest producer of Canadian oil, with high financial stability and potential for further scaling of export activities. With CNQ's per-barrel production costs significantly lower than those of its main industry competitors in North America, it has the guarantee of maintaining positive financial results during a downturn in the oil market.

Moreover, new sanctions against Russia's oil industry could potentially halt Russian oil supplies to China and India. If the capacity of the Trans Mountain pipeline is fully utilized, Canadian Natural Resources could increase its oil supplies by concluding new agreements with Chinese oil refineries. Moreover, for oil prices, the new sanctions against Russian oil companies are an additional factor that, if not raising the cost of hydrocarbons, then at least halting its decline in the short and medium term.

Considering CNQ's positive outlook and competitive advantages, I recommend these shares as a "Buy." In this article, I will reveal more detailed information about the reasons behind my decision. That said, I am not an active supporter of the bullish camp when it comes to oil companies. For instance, my latest fundamental analysis of the oil company Civitas Resources (CIVI) resulted in a "Sell" recommendation. I see a similar assessment for most participants in the North American oil market, due to the previously negative impact of fundamental factors.

Read more here...

PLTY: Close To Covered Call Perfection

Gary Bourgeault | Hold

YieldMax PLTR Option Income Strategy ETF (PLTY) is a covered call ETF primarily designed to generate income by incorporating a synthetic covered call strategy, meaning it doesn't own any of the underlying Palantir Technologies (PLTR) stock. It generates income from selling call options against the underlying.

The covered call strategy it uses caps much of the upside, but it also uses puts to mitigate some of the downside risk. That doesn't mean the share price of PLTY can't take off, because it has as I'll show you below. Even so, the chance of the ETF retaining large gains based upon the price surge of PLTR is very low.

Having said that, the reason I assert PLTY is close to covered call perfection, is it is operating exactly how a healthy covered call ETF should.

Read more here...

The AI Hype Could End Early For Power Solutions International

Alpha Mantra | Hold

The AI hype has turned the fortunes of many stocks in the last 2 years, making once-overlooked companies into hot stocks. One of the stocks riding this AI bandwagon has been Power Solutions International, Inc. (PSIX), which has surged 20-fold in a matter of ~two years. The meteoric rise of PSIX has been driven by its timely pivot toward catering to AI data center-related demand as opposed to its legacy business catering to the industrial and transportation sector.

I believe the demand related to data centers continues to be robust, with hyperscalers and other cloud providers either setting up or pledging to set up multi-gigawatt-scale data centers. While PSIX should benefit from this tailwind, I believe its unique position as a lesser-established player in the industry makes it vulnerable as the competitive industry brews up and customers switch back to more established players. Furthermore, a significant stake sale by an insider further makes me cautious about PSIX's prospects.

While my outlook is quite cautious on the stock, I am refraining from issuing a sell rating, particularly due to good fundamental momentum in the data center space. I would like to wait for a confirmation sign that competitive intensity is growing and materially affecting PSIX’s numbers, particularly margins. Until then, I would be sitting on the sidelines with a hold (neutral) rating on the stock.

Read more here...

NuScale: Danger Signs On Meltdown Of Speculative Froth

JR Research | Hold

I've never been that interested in investing in energy companies, let alone companies that specialize in nuclear energy technology like NuScale Power Corporation (SMR). However, 2025 has been a real eye-opener even to a seasoned investor and market watcher that I consider myself to be, as the stock of money-losing companies has continued its rampaging run. That said, I'm not particularly perturbed about missing "big speculative opportunities" if they aren't backed by solid fundamentals.

Also, I'm not especially keen on scooping up so-called "undervalued" plays in the fundamentally/structurally challenged sectors of the market (like the oil and gas peers, some healthcare plays, etc.). Investors who position the majority of their portfolios in these sectors have arguably missed out on partaking in the advance impelled by the tech and Mag 7 stocks as they demonstrate their AI prowess while also continuing to build their clout in this fourth industrial AI revolution.

I brought up the issue of speculative opportunities earlier because I believe SMR stock falls right into such a setup. It's not a coincidence that SMR is also the acronym for "small modular reactor" as much as it refers specifically to the ticker symbol for NuScale Power. What's critical for investors to note is that the company has consistently positioned itself as a key technology enabler or provider, encompassing its burgeoning partnership with ENTRA1, while also relying on Doosan as its key manufacturing partner. The reportedly asset-light approach is designed to help NuScale potentially avoid the CapEx complexities and financing challenges entailed with being a developer while also benefiting from the manufacturing expertise of a trusted supply chain partner.

Yet, the drawback suggests that it's imperative for NuScale to manage the supply chain dynamics extremely well in this early stage of the SMR buildout, even though it has obtained NRC approval. In addition, I believe we must also be cognizant of the challenges that encompass the multi-year rollout of NuScale's ability to scale, given the investments it has made in long-lead materials this year to pave the runway for a 2030 commercial operation date status, which is pivotal to justifying the extremely frothy valuation metrics that complement its investment thesis right now.

Read more here...

DroneShield: Potential For Exponential Revenue Growth

Stephen Tobin | Strong Buy

DroneShield (OTCPK:DRSHF) is an Australian company that manufactures counter-drone systems. With deployed solutions in 50 countries, it has become the market leader in this burgeoning industry. (I will use A$ to signify when I am writing about Australian dollar amounts.)

The sector has enormous growth potential, benefiting from industry tailwinds as countries gear up their defence against drones that have proven so effective and difficult to counter in recent conflicts.

I believe the company has a good chance of increasing its revenue from the reported A$58 million in 2024 to A$2.5 billion by 2030. That's a 4,200% increase and could catapult the company's share price from today's A$5 to over A$50.

DroneShield technology provides a sustainable competitive advantage, and it is gearing up its manufacturing operations to give it the capacity to hit the $2.5 billion sales target by the end of 2026 with new facilities expected to come online in Europe (Q1) and the US (Q3).

Read more here...

Deckers: Q2 Sell-Off Created A Buying Opportunity

Caffital Research | Buy

Deckers Outdoor Corporation (DECK) reported the company’s fiscal Q2 results from the July-September period on the 23rd of October. The footwear company continued to show strength in the two primary brands, HOKA and UGG, but a weaker-than-expected FY2026 sales guidance has sent the stock down -11% in pre-market action at the time of writing.

I cautiously remained at a Hold rating in my previous July article, titled “Deckers: An Attractive Entry Point Is Nearing”. The stock has since lost -14% of its value, continuing to underperform the S&P 500's 8% return. I believe that an attractive entry point is finally here, as the market has become overly concerned.

Read more here...

Canadian Natural: Undervalued Strength In A Volatile Oil Market

Louis Gerard | Strong Buy

It has been a couple of months since I last reviewed Canadian Natural Resources, and it has been a roller coaster of emotions for the Oil & Gas industry following the decline in crude prices. CNQ has shown a total return of 2.67% since, and I believe that with the company’s Q3 earnings incoming, CNQ should be closely followed by value investors.

As a reminder to readers, Canadian Natural Resources Limited (CNQ) (CNQ:CA) is one of the largest independent oil & gas producers, not only in Canada but in the world. It currently owns a diversified set of production with both oil sands and conventional and natural gas.

Read more here...

United Parcel Service: Back On Track, Cash Flow Supports Dividend

Ragmar Rikberg | Buy

With more and more headlines pointing to stock market overvaluation and at least some degree of correction seemingly around the corner, I believe this is the perfect time to turn some attention toward defensive stocks. They say it's wise to take a safe position while the music’s still playing and the lights are on. And even if the party lasts longer than expected, it's always smart to have some, maybe not the front-line growers, but great value stocks in your portfolio.

In my opinion, one area worth exploring for relatively safe plays is the category of so-called “fallen angels” — solid leaders with well-established businesses that are currently facing turbulence. However, if the issues seem to be rather temporary ones, the business model isn’t broken, the financials remain within a credible range, and competitive management is in place, then these companies could be well-positioned for recovery.

Easy to say, hard to find — at least in my experience. Still, I carved out some dedicated time and started digging and ended up with two companies I think are worth a closer look. One of them, which I started reviewing last week, had an earnings release just around the corner, offers an 11% dividend, runs a somewhat old-fashioned and sluggish — but definitely not broken — business, has strong financials, and has a solid story that suggests stability, maybe even some growth ahead. If there’s interest, one could check it out here.

The other one that fell within my criteria was United Parcel Service, Inc. (UPS). That’s where I’m reminded of an old Warren Buffett saying: it’s better to invest in a business you understand. It wasn’t exactly phrased like that word-for-word, but the broader meaning holds true to me. And I think, broadly and simply put, delivering packages around the world and right to the doorstep is a business most people can grasp more easily than, say, quantum computing. A 7.5% dividend yield is very attractive, and a forward-looking P/E of 13.5 made me want to dig deeper to see if I’m not missing a great opportunity here.

Having done the analysis, I rate UPS as a Buy. In my view, the current struggles are fixable, and the likelihood of a successful turnaround is relatively high. Even if finding firmer footing takes time, the dividend looks sustainable for now — unless something truly extraordinary happens.

Read more here...

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: AMLP: 4 Elements I Like To Remember About MLPs
data.description:
When I think of an income-oriented sector, with distributions uncorrelated to classic income investing instruments, I think of the MLP segment. Now, the leader in terms of AUM on the market is the Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP), and in some ways, I understand the enthusiasm. It offers high yield, it offers tax simplicity, and it has targeted exposure to the MLP segment, not to mention the macroeconomic stimuli that drive demand for stocks in this segment.

But are we sure it’s really the number one solution in this sector? Personally, I identify 4 discussion points to open.

  1. it’s too concentrated

  2. it doesn’t hold up against peers

  3. tax simplicity is not a fiscal advantage and

  4. it doesn’t have such clear positive catalysts.

Let me explain better.

What is AMLP

When we talk about AMLP, we’re talking about a leading ETF in the MLP segment, with an AUM of about $10.4B. Yet its investment strategy is very simple: it’s a passive ETF with the Alerian MLP Index (float-adjusted, cap-weighted) as its benchmark and an expense ratio of 0.85%. So the core remains U.S. energy MLPs (oil & gas pipelines), with a specific focus on the midstream energy segment (transport & storage).

1) Holding distribution: high concentration.

A first element to discuss is certainly the holding distribution. It consists of 15 100% U.S. MLPs, where the top 6 holdings cover 75% of the distribution and the top 10 weight almost 93.2%.

Can we therefore say that AMLP is quite concentrated? Yes, although it still represents well the various segments of this sector.

However, it must be said that it remains a holding distribution very easily replicable independently, even with a sampling mechanism, considering the strong concentration, but also a turnover around 20% (indicating few rebalancings), and a portfolio volatility of 14 points.

But without going into the details of sampling strategies, this is also shown simply by the linearity of AMLP with Western Midstream Partners, LP (WES), the first holding (about 12%) of AMLP.

2) Peer

Continuing in this direction, the reference peers are Global X MLP ETF (MLPA), Global X MLP & Energy Infrastructure ETF (MLPX), and the broader ENFR in terms of holdings.

It’s immediately noticeable that AMLP is the ETF with the largest AUM in circulation ($10.3B). At the same time, it’s also the most expensive, and if we look at total return, also the least profitable, both in the short and long term.

I already expressed my concerns about this in MLPA, which, although it looks at the global market, still shows a historical performance very close to AMLP (read here). And I had already stated that MLPX would in my opinion be a more competitive pick in this segment (read here). What I personally appreciate, and I recognize it may be debatable, is the presence of a structural mix that goes beyond AMLP’s concentration. In MLPX, for example, there are holdings both of midstream MLPs and energy infrastructure corporations, which is why the holding distribution broadens and total performance increases. An element that, in my opinion, is further amplified in ENFR.

Why is it so attractive?

I’ll get straight to the point, the reason why this sector is chosen, despite a capital loss of about 37% since 2010, is in my opinion the high yield element, which today is very competitive, equal to 8.3% distributed quarterly;

And it’s, in my opinion, an expression of the genuineness of the MLP segment in general (not just AMLP): not by chance there’s a good coverage ratio of the distribution, between 45% – 70%. And at the same time the sector shows good valuations: the forward EV/EBITDA is today 8.6x, which however is below the three-year average of 8.77x, with a leverage target of 2.7x – 3.2x.

Another clue is the fact that the yield has been in an upward trend for 5 years now where, very curiously, we are witnessing a certain dividend trend accelerating (3Y > 5Y). A signal of strong momentum from the midstream energy sector.

This pushes the total return into positive territory (+99% in about 15 years), which has progressively attracted more and more income investors, used to working with DRIP strategy.

And it’s a competitive yield even compared to peers. Only MLPA offers a similar structure in terms of distribution. In the others, the inclusion of parallel segments lowers the distribution.

3) The tax structure

I start with a disclaimer in my opinion very important here: the tax impact of any instrument varies depending on one’s own tax regime. So, these considerations should not be considered exhaustive: they only reflect my personal reflection and experience.

But a good chapter could be opened in this sense. This is because AMLP is not a RIC, therefore it has deferred tax liabilities theoretically positive. In this sense, the benefit of the MLPs is lost and in my personal opinion this is the reason why there is an evident divergence in performance compared to the reference index. Discussing it with other bank advisor colleagues, it seems that often the “tax simplicity” is preferred to the “convenience,” and on this I have no doubts. For this reason it is a very subjective reasoning, and I only bring you my opinion. But I repeat: personally, this leads me even more to prefer MLP stock picking.

NB: moving to the side of share distribution; it is always over 70% ROC, an element that as you know instead is associated with tax benefits (reduces the tax basis of the shares).

4) Catalysts? Which ones?

Behind the rebound of the segment there are certainly many interesting narratives. In my opinion, the prevailing one is the boom in demand coming from AI/data centers build-out. Contextualizing more based on the recent news of these weeks, there seem to be 2 other potential positive catalysts: the new U.S. sanctions against Russia but also the Fed rate cuts. This generates primarily positive pressure on the price of oil, and secondly, a potential boost for the commodities segment (because industrial expectations increase). If we add to this the pullback of about 10% since April 2025, it seems like a real opportunity.

Yet, some clarifications are needed.

Risk?

The risk of AMLP, shared also by its peers and by individual MLPs, is that they are linked to oil production. But attention, here a not insignificant disconnection is created in my opinion.

When expectations related to oil production decline, MLPs price in a potential negative cycle in their fundamentals. But this does not make AMLP an “oil price beta” ETF. And we can see the divergence in the positive tail of the return distribution.

At a fundamental level what happens? That if expectations on production fall, expectations on EBITDA fall, therefore on the coverage ratio and on the yield. And this generates a capital outflow.

The thing that for now makes me remain confident in the sector is the issue of inflation, which is often integrated into contracts (built-in inflation protection). This is why since 2022 this sector has held up well through the economic cyclical rotation. Secondly, the intentions confirmed by OPEC to increase production, not reduce it.

Conclusion

I think the MLP segment can truly help diversify the portfolio’s income sources and provide good capital preservation. On AMLP, although it is a leader in the sector, I find some weaknesses I couldn’t overlook. Considering the strong concentration, the tax burden, the presence of more competitive peers, and ultimately the lack of a clear short-term catalyst, I think the right rating for AMLP is Hold.

data.title: Vale: Another LATAM Giant With Good Prospects
data.description:
Vale S.A. (NYSE:VALE) is a producer and miner of minerals for various commercial production purposes, primarily iron ore, but also nickel and copper, due to the structure of its mines and deposits in its portfolio. Its business is primarily focused on Latin America, especially Brazil, but it also owns and manages deposits in North America and Asia. Iron ore is undoubtedly Vale's main product. It represents a total of 84 million tons of production, compared to 40,000 tons of nickel and 93,000 tons of copper.

Over the past year, the company has experienced a decline in revenue due to a fall in the international price of iron ore. This decline began rapidly in 2022 but has continued since January 2024, where it had last recovered. This trend is closely linked to the slowdown in Chinese economic growth. It is important to understand this concept because the Asian giant currently accounts for more than 50% of global steel production, the main raw material of which is iron ore.

Still, as I will try to describe in this report, especially in the following thesis segment, the characteristics of VALE as a company and the potential it has in the short and medium term.

Thesis

As previously mentioned, VALE maintains a stake in Latin America, North America, and Asia. Without a doubt, LATAM is the leading geographic region in terms of the number of tons of potentially exploitable reserves. In comparison, LATAM represents more reserves than the total estimated for Asia and North America combined.

It is true, as we mentioned, that the international price of iron ore has been steep since 2022, with the end of the pandemic and the sharp slowdown in China's growth. In this sense, the Asian giant represents one of the main demanders of this commodity, based on the fact that the country is the world's leading steel producer. Therefore, understanding China's performance in the short term is key to the future of the international price of iron ore.

Now, the question arises as to what could happen in the medium and long term. In this sense, it is necessary to understand the growth in demand that other countries and regions may experience. As can be seen below, VALE expects that, on the iron ore demand side, China will continue to show a downward trend in the medium term. However, the trend is expected to increase, driven by greater participation from India and other countries outside the main demanders at this time.

Regarding these forecasts, from my perspective, it's important to note that the expectation for India's growth is well-founded. According to some specialized websites, steel production in India is expected to grow by approximately 9% in the short term. Regarding the company's forecasts for China and its demand for iron ore, they appear to be rather conservative. Much of the market expects demand for this mineral from the Asian giant to remain strong, which could offer a better short-term outlook than the company anticipates.

Moving on to the iron ore supply, as long as international prices remain stable, VALE expects a significant portion of iron ore mines to return to profitability, leading to a recovery in production from there. However, they estimate that even then, they will not be able to cope with even more significant demand growth by 2030. These highlights price pressure that could be beneficial for the industry. This could not only lead to a recovery in the company's margins, but also, given the increase in production that VALE is expected to drive, a significant increase in revenue.

In this regard, the year 2025 represented a significant increase compared to 2024 in terms of copper and nickel tonnage. While it's true that the increase in iron ore was a smaller percentage, it grew by around 3.7% compared to 2024. Considering the volumes this metal represents in VALE's total production, we see that, from my perspective, an increase of this magnitude is interesting and attractive.
