Looking ahead and toward margin recovery, it's interesting to see the company's achievements in reducing or controlling costs. While major competitors saw an increase in extraction costs per ton in 2025 compared to 2023, VALE was the exception. This year, the company reported a drop to between $20.5 and $22 per ton, and the trend is expected to continue and fall to less than $20 per ton by 2026.

To delve deeper into the topic of margins, it's interesting to see that VALE's margin percentages are well above the industry average. This positions it as one of the top players among iron ore mining companies and makes it an excellent option to take advantage of the cycle change and the supply-demand spread I mentioned earlier.

2Q2025 Results

In this segment, I would like to summarize Vale's results for the second quarter of 2025 and compare them with previous periods. First, I want to focus on production changes, and then move on to the financial results. In this regard, Vale's total iron ore production during the second quarter of 2025 was 77.35 million metric tons. This figure, compared to the 79.79 million metric tons produced in the second quarter of 2024, represents a decrease of approximately 3%. Furthermore, compared to the first quarter of 2024, production grew 17% compared to the 66.14 million metric tons produced in the first quarter.

Regarding the international price of iron ore, the downward trend mentioned in the thesis segment can be seen. As can be seen, Vale's realized price of the commodity in 2Q2025 was $97.8/ton, while in 1Q2025 it was $103.6/ton, representing a drop of approximately 6%. Compared to 2Q2024, the drop was approximately 13% compared to the $111.8/ton reported by the company.

I would now like to analyze the main financial results reported by VALE. Regarding revenues, the company reported a result of $8.8 billion in the second quarter of 2025. This represented an 11% decrease compared to the $9.9 billion for the same period in 2024. However, when we analyze it compared to the first quarter of 2025 figures, we see an 8% increase compared to the $8.12 billion for that period. This continues to reflect the trend described at the beginning of this section.

Let's now analyze the company's reported EBITDA figures. VALE reported a total of $3,386 million in 2Q2025. Again, compared to the figures reported in 2Q2024, we see a 15% drop compared to the $3,993 million reported in that period. Again, compared to 1Q2025, we see an increase of approximately 9% compared to the $3,115 million reported in that quarter. It's interesting to analyze the EV/EBITDA ratio. Annualizing the previously described figures, we can calculate a ratio of approximately 4.99x.

Another interesting point was the quarter-over-quarter decline in CapEx and compared to last year. In Q2 2025, the company's reported CapEx was $1,053 million, a 10% decrease compared to the $1,173 million reported in Q1 2025. The decline is even greater compared to Q2 2024.

Valuation

For this segment, I developed a DCF model, in order to further contribute to the description of the company and the scenario in which it operates, in light of what can be expected. In this regard, I first describe the assumptions I used to perform the calculations. Regarding the tax rate, I used 18%. While it may seem low compared to other industries, when examining the effective rate in Seeking Alpha's Financials segment, according to the data reported by the company, it can be seen that the average for recent years is below that value. I deliberately decided to perform the calculations with a higher rate to generate a margin of safety in the company's valuation.

Regarding the perpetual growth rate, I decided to use a value of 2%, which is slightly below global GDP growth in recent decades, a value to which the demand for steel, and therefore for iron ore, is closely linked. Again, the idea behind this selection was to maintain a margin of safety in relation to the company's final valuation. Regarding the WACC, I would like to explain in a little more detail why I believe a value of 10% contributes more to that margin of safety. First, when analyzing the capital structure, we can see that Vale has a market capitalization of $45.67 billion and a debt stock of $20.39 billion. This generates a debt and equity-to-total assets ratio of 30.9% and 69.1%, respectively.

Regarding the cost of debt, the volume-weighted average of bonds issued gives the company a yield of around 5.34%. In this sense, a WACC of 10% would imply a cost of equity of 12.08%, which, considering the company's beta of approximately 1.02, seems reasonable, even considering that the company's primary business is in emerging countries. In fact, when we look at specialized sites, we can see that the WACC they assign to the company is around 6.5%, considerably lower than the one I decided to choose. This is undoubtedly where I tried to be more conservative, charging a penalty precisely because of the risks inherent in the countries in which Vale operates, but also as confirmation of the generation of the safety margin I've been mentioning.

Regarding EBITDA growth, I proposed a 5% increase for the first year, 4.5% for the second, 4% for the third, 3% for the fourth, and 2.5% for the fifth, aligning with the same growth rate in perpetuity thereafter. While this may seem like a high-growth rate, as can be seen in the table below, market analysts' forecasts indicate an EPS of $1.81, while the value for 2024 was $1.42. Considering this increase, it can be seen that a 5% increase in EBITDA is quite conservative. Regarding amortization and depreciation, to simplify the calculations, I assumed they would grow at a rate equal to that of EBITDA. Finally, regarding CapEx, I estimated a constant growth of 1.5% throughout the period.

Finally, taking all these assumptions into consideration, it can be seen that the company has attractive upside potential. It's important to note that this value is obtained even under the conservative assumptions that sought to generate a margin of safety. From my perspective, these results reinforce the scenario and forecasts detailed in the thesis segment and provide further justification for the BUY rating.

Risks And Conclusion

Finally, I would like to mention the main risks that may be looming in the short term. Without a doubt, the most important to note, from my perspective, is the change in foreign trade policy undertaken by the United States government. The White House's initiative to increase import tariffs on the vast majority of countries has China as one of the main targets.

Given the impact this Asian country represents on steel production and iron ore demand, the escalation of the situation could be a major risk. While it is true that other players are expected to drive demand in the medium term, the fact that Chinese economic growth does not recover or, worse still, declines as a result of a trade war with the United States, could affect the transition period and generate a further downward trend in iron ore prices in the short term.

Still, due to the geographic location of VALE's business, I believe the Brazilian company is better positioned than some other competitors to address the risks. Given the scenario I sought and the company's valuation, I believe VALE has good growth prospects and can benefit greatly from a change in the cycle. At the same time, it has the qualities to withstand a continuation of the trend experienced by iron ore in recent years. Therefore, I consider the company a BUY.

data.title: Highlights From The Trump Administration's East Asia Deals
data.description:
In the week beginning on October 24, 2025, President Trump and his administration met with East Asian leaders. The President stopped first in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, followed by Japan and South Korea. Last, but not least, and most importantly, he met with Chinese President Xi on Thursday, Oct. 30.

What did the meeting with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (“ASEAN”) accomplish?

Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand

The White House segmented the President’s deals into three groups: peace deals, trade deals, and critical minerals deals. The peace deal might have minimal interest to readers, since defense firms like Lockheed Martin Corporation (LMT), The Boeing Company (BA), or RTX Corporation (RTX). Product sales for defense contractors are bigger in other markets and countries. For example, RTX stock jumped by 6.11% in the last month to continue its yearlong uptrend.

RTX posted resilient strength in commercial aerospace, thanks to passenger air travel resiliency. In addition, Pratt Canada serviced nearly 70,000 engines. RTX’s backlog grew by 13% Y/Y to $251 billion. Its book-to-bill in Q3 was 1.63. Collins and Pratt’s customers included NASA, General Electric Company (GE), SpaceX, and Textron Inc. (TXT).

Malaysia and Cambodia eliminated tariffs on U.S. exports. While that expands market access for U.S. products, the White House posted that “non-tariff barriers will be addressed.”

Malaysia (EWM) imported $299.5 billion in 2024. The U.S. accounted for $27.60 billion. China accounted for 24%, according to Trading Economics:

Cambodia imported $28.71 billion. Again, China was its biggest source of imports at 48%, compared to $264.17 million from the U.S.

Vietnam (VNM) Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and President Trump announced a joint statement on a U.S.-Vietnam Framework for an Agreement on Reciprocal, Fair, and Balanced Trade. The deal is incomplete. A fact sheet issued that day stated that the two countries would continue to negotiate in the coming weeks to finalize the deal.

Vietnam exports will face a 20% tariff. Any transshipment from third countries faces a 40% duty. Still, Vietnam will improve market access by resolving constraints that U.S. exports face. For example, it would recognize vehicles that meet U.S. safety and emission standards. Vietnam would simplify regulatory approvals for U.S. pharmaceutical products.

Vietnam Airlines signed a deal to buy 50 Boeing aircraft worth $8 billion.

To get an idea of Vietnam’s market size, look at the $379 billion imports in 2024. This grew by 7.2% Y/Y. China and Vietnam reached $144.3 billion worth of trade in 2024-25. The U.S. remained a key trade partner, where imports totaled $14.3 billion. It supplied Vietnam, which focused on agriculture, machinery, technology, and rubber.

Thailand agreed to eliminate tariffs on 99% of goods. Thailand (THD) will buy U.S. agricultural, energy products and aircraft. This has a value of over $20 billion.

Deal With Japan

Japan (EWJ) and the U.S. signed an agreement where the U.S. would tax goods imported from Japan at 15%. Japan agreed to create a $550 billion fund of investments in the U.S. Japanese firms expressed interest in launching projects in the U.S. worth around $400 billion in total. They want to invest in energy, which AI infrastructure requires to run. Still, the Japan Times reported that the deal did not finalize any of the projects.

Honda Motor Co., Ltd. (HMC), Toyota Motor Corporation (TM), and Sony Group Corporation (SONY) are among the biggest firms to watch. Tariffs have an impact on their export volumes.

Above: Sony is the first in its industry rank, while Toyota scores a B or higher in all of its quant factor grades.

China Deal

The U.S. did not sign a trade deal when the two leaders met for less than two hours (as reported by CNN). This was a face-to-face talk in Busan, South Korea (EWY), which was their first meeting since 2019. Trump agreed to lower tariffs on Chinese exports to 47%, down from 57%. The U.S. will cut the tariff rates related to fentanyl precursor drugs by half, to 10%.

China agreed to pause (delay for one year), not cancel, export controls on rare earths. Similarly, Treasury Secretary Bessent confirmed that the U.S. would pause its new expansion of export controls. This freezes the 50% BIS (Bureau of Industry and Security) rule. The rule would have extended last year’s announced export-licensing requirements. That would have applied to firms that were majority-owned by parties on the entity list, military end-user list, or part of the specially designated nationals.

China agreed to buy 12 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans until January 2026. It will buy 25 million tons a year for the next three years. China bought 28.8 million tons on average in the last five September-to-August crop seasons. Soybean (SOYB) prices have jumped since October 10. SOYB stock is up by around 6.5% in the last month.

Bessent said that China approved the transfer agreement for TikTok. A Chinese spokesperson said, “The Chinese side will work with the U.S. side to properly address issues related to TikTok." Ahead of the news, Oracle Corporation (ORCL), considered a frontrunner in acquiring the short-form video site, underperformed. ORCL stock potentially peaked at around $340. The stock has spiked at lower highs since September and is down by 7.68% in the last week.

Trump said on Truth Social that China would buy U.S. oil and gas. Additionally, he announced a “very large-scale transaction (that) may take place” involving Alaska. Some liquefied natural gas stocks to explore further include Cheniere Energy, Inc. (LNG), Kinder Morgan, Inc. (KMI), and Energy Transfer LP (ET). ConocoPhillips (COP) is Alaska’s biggest oil producer. Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) has a stake in the Prudhoe Bay oil field, but Hilcorp replaced it as the operator in 2021.

Above: XOM stock has the highest sector rank. It has a 'Strong Buy' on Seeking Alpha's Quant Ratings.

Potential Economic Impact

Readers who craved for firm trade deals might be disappointed. The U.S. and China paused tariffs and restrictions, respectively, for one year. They will continue to play their long game using short-term agreements in principle. Investors will need to exercise caution in holding companies that struggled before tariffs. For example, Newell Brands Inc. (NWL) lost 32% despite indicating the impact of tariffs subsiding in 2026.

China is not faring well economically. Weaker exports, hurt by U.S. tariffs, resulted in factory activity falling to a six-month low. China’s (FXI) NBS Manufacturing PMI fell to 49.0%. Investors would not likely notice the weak data. FXI stock is up by 25% in the last year. The country’s technology stocks are up, too. Alibaba Group Holding Limited (BABA) gained 98.8% and Tencent Holdings Limited (OTCPK:TCEHY) is up by 51.8% YTD. Technology investors need not worry about the absence of discussing NVIDIA Corporation's (NVDA) Blackwell chip sales to China. The AI race to the top will continue between the U.S. and China.

Above: In the five-day period, shares of Tencent, Baidu, Inc. (BIDU), Alibaba, and JD.com, Inc. (JD) pulled back. Below: BIDU and JD shares offer compelling value.

Your Takeaway

Stock markets trade near their all-time highs. In the last week, earnings reports from the Magnificent Seven, along with the Federal Reserve’s 25 bps rate cut, influenced markets heavily. In the coming weeks, the U.S. will get a better idea of the impact of the deals with ASEAN nations, especially with China.
